ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

LOSS OF TRADE UNION FUNDS
(Call for Commission of Inquiry)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Prime Minister if he will recommend to the President the appointment of a Commission with all necessary terms of reference to inquire fully into the loss of monies belonging to members of Trade Unions between the years 1975 and 1979 and to report in as full a manner as is possible in all the circumstances inter alia on (i) the

Column: 362

total of all monies lost; (ii) the manner in which or how the monies were taken or lost; (iii) whether all recognized accounting practices and audit procedures had been followed in the keeping of the accounts; (iv) whether any officers in the member Trade Unions or the National Trades Union Congress should be held accountable for the loss/defalcation because of any failure on their part to take corrective measures to prevent any loss of monies and if so what action should be taken against them; and (v) the circumstances in which the former President of the N.T.U.C. Mr Phey Yew Kok was

Column: 363

enabled to leave the country after he had been charged in the courts.

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot recommend to the President the approval of a Commission to inquire into the matters set out in the question. It is a long question, with five limbs. They cover the six charges standing against Phey Yew Kok in the Criminal District Court - four for criminal breach of trust and two for contravention of the Trade Unions Act. There is a warrant out for his arrest for not answering to bail. I find it difficult to believe that as a lawyer, the Member for Anson is ignorant of the legal improprieties implicit in his suggestion that a Commission of Inquiry to investigate matters which, inter alia, must form part of the evidence on which these charges will rest.

    As long as there are reasonable prospects of bringing Phey Yew Kok to trial, nothing should be done which can be said to jeopardise the process of law. The Member for Anson is inviting me to investigate the facts, or to appoint a Commission to investigate the facts, of a criminal case which is sub judice when, in his own civil suit, pending on appeal to the Privy Council, he took immediate objection to a completely neutral reference I made in this House to the implications of the outcome for him, without touching on the merits of his appeal. However, not to be the Government's own legal officer, I asked for the opinion of the Attorney-General. In a written opinion, he has advised against the appointment of a Commission of Inquiry. I have made copies (Cols. 465 - 472) and handed them to the Clerk of Parliament for circulation to Honourable Members.
copies - OPINION (Cols. 465 - 472)


    Notwithstanding this, I can state that investigations made by the CPIB disclose that altogether $698,862.68 of monies belonging to SILO, PIEU and the NTUC Travel Services (Pte) Ltd, are unaccounted for. These investigations are not closed. I must add that there were no allegations, nor is there any evidence, of missing or unaccounted funds in the NTUC. There

Column: 364

were CBT offences committed on monies belonging to the NTUC Travel Services (Pte) Ltd. This is a private limited company, totally separate from the NTUC.

    Out of the CPIB investigations, ten other persons besides Phey Yew Kok were charged - nine convicted, one acquitted. I have made out a list of these persons, marked Annex 2, (Cols. 473 - 480) and handed it to the Clerk for Honourable Members. From the list, Members will see that three were officers of the trade unions SILO/PIEU, three were employees of SILO Multi-Purpose Co-operative Society Ltd, one the general manager of NTUC Travel Services (Pte) Ltd, one a public accountant (No. 10 in Annex 2), and one a Director of Savewell Supermarket (Pte) Ltd (No. 4 in Annex 2). Their charges, brief facts and the results are as set out in Annex 2. One (No. 3 in Annex 2) was acquitted. One (No. 11 in Annex 2) had been dealt with internally by PIEU and dismissed on 10th January 1978. The Attorney-General had advised against prosecution in Case No. 11. Annex 2 (Cols. 473 - 480)

    As monies misappropriated have been traced and found to have been used as part of the purchase price of a house at 53B Lorong Ong Lye, now in the name of Madam Wong Chui Ping (Mrs Phey Yew Kok), a caveat has been entered against this property. Briefly, no wrong-doing has been covered-up, nor has any wrong-doer been let-off, as the question has sought to imply. If the Member for Anson wants to, there can be an inquiry on whether there has been a cover-up. But the inquiry cannot cover the evidence on which the charges against Phey Yew Kok are founded.

    The Minister for Home Affairs will provide the answer in Question No. 10 on what happened to Phey Yew Kok.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am indebted to the Prime Minister for the lengthy statement. As I understand it, it would be contempt of court to inquire into it while proceedings are pending before a criminal court, but

Column: 365

the trial has not begun as yet. It is, in m view, always open to the prosecution to withdraw for the moment the charge against Mr Phey Yew Kok and that he be discharged not amounting to an acquittal and then an inquiry held, and when Mr Phey Yew Kok is apprehended and brought into this country he can be freshly put on trial on those charges. Would the Prime Minister like to consider that?

     The Prime Minister: I am asked, if I may state what the Member for Anson has suggested, to do the following: Get the Attorney-General to enter nolle prosequi or to withdraw the charges which -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: A discharge not amounting to an acquittal.

     The Prime Minister: There are two steps the Attorney-General can take - enter a nolle prosequi or withdraw the charges. Which does he propose the Attorney-General should do?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was not suggesting that there should be a nolle prosequi entered. From my own experience it has very often been the case that the Prosecution - where a witness is absent or is not available to give evidence - consent to the accused being discharged, such discharge not amounting to an acquittal, and then the case is again brought up when the witnesses are found. That is my experience in the courts.

     The Prime Minister: We are asked now to get the Attorney-General to withdraw the charges not amounting to an acquittal. The warrant for his arrest will then be automatically treated as lapsed, because there are no charges pending.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Warrants can be applied for again on those charges immediately after that, and it often happens that warrants are applied far from the courts and issued even when persons are out of the country.

     The Prime Minister: As I understand it, I am now being asked to suggest to the

Column: 366

Attorney-General to go into an elaborate subterfuge. In other words, the Member for Anson, in putting his question which is really to create a smear that there has been a cover-up, knew that he was suggesting something improper and had come prepared for an answer that this was being thwarted because it is sub judice, and therefore he proposes that we withdraw the charge; warrant will lapse; commission of inquiry is held, Phey Yew Kok's trial in effect is held by the commission of inquiry; all the issues involved are prejudged; the commission reports, charges are then reintroduced; warrants for arrest are reissued. Is that what is being seriously suggested - that a government should require its Attorney-General to do because a Member of the Opposition wants to satisfy his curiosity?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I was not attempting smears. I would ask the Prime Minister not to impute too readily motives to the Opposition Member. The terms of inquiry of the commission can be drafted in such a way as to exclude any inquiry as to the guilt or otherwise of Mr Phey Yew Kok. The inquiry can be directed as to how - I have set out some of the matters on which the inquiry can be conducted, and that is whether accounting and correct accounting and audit practices, procedures, had been followed and whether anybody else was aware of the manner in which these moneys were being taken from the amounts held by these unions.

     The Prime Minister: The commission of inquiry was supposed to have terms of reference which would cover the question set out: to report in as full a manner as possible in all the circumstances, interalia, on (i), (ii), (iii), (iv) and (v). This has been spelt out. I am suggesting to the Member that he must know that this is improper. It must cover the grounds on which the evidence against Phey Yew Kok rest, including the system by which he siphoned off the money. How can we have this elaborate deception of withdrawing the charge, allowing the warrants for arrest to lapse, have a Commission of Inquiry, find out how it was that monies were siphoned off, and then re-institute the charges? If the Member for Anson

Column: 367

wants Mr Phey Yew Kok to have a good defence, that is exactly what he would do. He could then turn up and get the Member for Anson, or indeed any other lawyer in town, to go to court and say that a fair trial has been prejudiced.

    Surely I am offering the Member, and perhaps he was not listening to me carefully, what he really wants to know is whether there has been a cover-up, whether anybody has been let off. I am prepared to have such a commission without touching the evidence against Phey Yew Kok because such an inquiry will be a credit to the Government. It will show how thoroughly and impartially an investigation was conducted against a very senior and close associate of several Ministers in the Government and of the President, and how it was relentlessly pursued until no evidence was left unturned and that he was not allowed to get away and abscond because the Government was afraid it would open up more horrendous skeletons in the cupboard. That is what I am offering, but without touching the evidence against Phey Yew Kok. Are you wanting that inquiry because I am quite happy to have it?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: If the Prime Minister will let me know the terms of reference of this commission that he proposes to appoint, then I will answer him?

     The Prime Minister: I am offering the Member a commission to investigate any alleged cover-up. He is alleging the cover up. Write it out without touching on the facts relating to Phey Yew Kok's charges, and he will have his commission.

     The Second Deputy Prime Minister (Foreign Affairs) (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Why don't you write to London?

     Mr Jeyaretnam rose -

     Mr Speaker: Mr Jeyaretnam, are you asking a supplementary question?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am replying to the Prime Minister.

Column: 368



     Mr Speaker: You should put a supplementary question, Mr Jeyaretnam.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Prime Minister then refer the terms to me on which he proposes to appoint a commission? I will then answer him.

     The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I know that he is at a loss for words. Take his time, compose himself, compose his thoughts, come back with the question at an appropriate time with an appropriate set of words which will exorcize the suspicions he has of any cover-up. Frame it in such a way that it does not touch upon the charges on which Phey Yew Kok has been brought to trial.

Column: 368

INHALANT ABUSE IN SCHOOLS
(Preventive measures)


    2. Mr Hwang Soo Jin asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education whether his Ministry is aware of the fact that some of our schoolchildren have been found to indulge in inhaling a certain type of rubber solution for its intoxicating effect and if he will instruct all school principals to take appropriate measures to prevent the spread of such dangerous indulgence.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry is aware that school children have been found to indulge in inhalant abuse. However, the indulgence is not widespread and the situation is well under control. In fact, the number of abusers inhaling paint thinners and glues in Singapore is not significant. The Central Narcotics Bureau apprehended 24 cases in 1980 and 73 cases in 1981. The majority of the cases involved youth in the age group of 15-19. Out of the total of 97 cases, 16 who were on record as drug addicts were sent to the Drug Rehabilitation Centres, four who were National Servicemen were dealt with by the SAF and three who were students were referred to the Social Work Unit of my Ministry for counselling. The remaining 74

Column: 369

experimenters were warned on the dangers of abuse of inhalants and were released.

    My Ministry is working closely with the Central Narcotics Bureau and principals have been instructed to be on the lookout for any cases of inhalant abuse in schools. Although there is little substantial evidence to show that inhalant abuse leads to physical dependence as is the case of the hard drugs, the grave dangers should still be pointed out to school students. Inhalant abuse can lead to total or partial amnesia. It is also known to impair vision and muscle control. Permanent damage to the nervous system, the brain, liver, kidneys and bone marrow have also been known to result from inhalant abuse.

Column: 369

EXCESSIVE HOMEWORK FOR SCHOOLCHILDREN


    3. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education whether schoolchildren are being over-pressured by excessive amount of homework and what steps his Ministry is taking to control the amount of homework that is being given to schoolchildren.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, a study was conducted in July 1981 by the Ministry on the amount of homework done by school children in Singapore. The average number of hours per week spent on homework were as follows:- 

  Primary School

  children                  6.8 hours



  Secondary School

  children                 18.5 hours


    82% of primary and secondary pupils and 75% of Pre-U pupils considered the amount of homework assigned by their teachers reasonable.

    These hours are not excessive by any standard. Comparison with Australian secondary school children which was

Column: 370

reported in a survey carried out in Western Australia show that their higher achievers do more homework than ours, namely, 25.7 hours per week against 19.7. The average for poor students is about the same; 16.9 to 19.4 hours for Australians, compared with 18.5 for Singaporeans.

    These are the averages. But averages conceal variations. There are children who do much less homework than the average and there are others who do much more. Those who do very much more - thereby causing anxiety in the mind of the Member for Chong Boon - could be of two types. First, they could be the more diligent and ambitious children. Second are children who have to put up with over-ambitious parents.

    Nothing need be done about the first group; little can be done about the second.

PHYSICAL EDUCATION IN SCHOOLS
(Steps to improve)


    4. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what steps are being taken by his Ministry to improve the teaching of physical education in schools.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the subject of improving physical education in. schools has been discussed at length within my Ministry and at meetings with the Schools Council. It is generally agreed that, with a few honourable exceptions, the standard of physical education instruction is poor. A good PE programme is a combination of curricular gymnastics, track and field activities, games and swimming. But such a programme requires trained PE teachers of whom, unfortunately, we have very few. My Ministry is therefore studying the feasibility of setting up a PE college to produce PE teachers in sufficient numbers.

    In the meantime, the physical fitness of boys has to be improved to better prepare them for National Service. My Ministry has therefore introduced a pilot swimming programme in six secondary schools, to

Column: 371

be followed by another 14 schools in 1982, to develop the physical fitness of boys. Under the swimming programme, PE lessons in these schools would be exclusively swimming. Swimming has been selected as a means to develop physical fitness of boys for the following reasons:

    (i) a swimming teacher can be trained in a relatively shorter time than an all-round PE teacher;

    (ii) a swimming pool is more effective in terms of space utilization than large playing fields in land-scarce Singapore a swimming pool can be used simultaneously by 80 or so persons in an area less than one-fifth of a playing field; and

    (iii) swimming is proven as a good exercise for developing aerobic capacity. The swimming programme will be extended to more schools as more teachers are trained as swimming instructors.

    At the same time, my Ministry has deployed the few trained PE teachers we have to 14 secondary schools and junior colleges in 1982 to teach a PE programme consisting of a combination of physical conditioning activities, curricular gymnastics, track and field and games to help improve the physical fitness of students.

Column: 371

COMPUTER CLUBS IN SECONDARY SCHOOLS
(Teaching of computer programmes)


    5. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education how many computer clubs here are in secondary schools and what steps his Ministry is taking to ensure that he computers are being used for the eaching of computer programmes and not for computer games.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are at present 91 computer clubs in secondary schools.

    My Ministry is preparing guidelines for the management and control of computer club activities in secondary schools. Micro-

Column: 372

computers will be used for educational purposes and not for video-games.

    Teachers have been trained to manage the computer clubs in schools and they will ensure that the microcomputers provided for the clubs are used for learning purposes, Computer games which are purely psychomotor in nature, e.g. Space Invaders and the like, will be disallowed. The average computer time available per student per week is about 30 minutes. This is barely enough for the pupils to complete their computer programming exercises and assignments, let alone play games.

     Mr S. Chandra Das (Chong Boon): Sir, can the Minister of State of Education inform the House how many teachers have been trained in computer programming?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, so far, we have trained 192 teachers for these computer clubs. Another 420 teachers will be trained this year and next year to provide the full complement.

Column: 372

PROMOTION EXERCISE FOR EDUCATION OFFICERS


    6. Mr Sia Khoon Seong asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education when the next promotion exercise for Education Officers will be held.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, no date has been fixed for a general promotion exercise for principals and teachers. It is unlikely that one will be held as previous exercises have merely resulted in a general demoralisation of the teaching service.

    The Ministry, together with the Public Service Commission and the Finance Ministry, is working on a better method of rewarding deserving principals and teachers.

Column: 372

RELIGIOUS EDUCATION IN SCHOOLS


    7. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of

Column: 373

Education how his Ministry will ensure that religious knowledge classes in schools will not be turned into conversion sessions.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, teachers of religious knowledge will be selected from those who belong to the established churches in the case of Christians. Those who are members of fundamentalist sects (which have a record of evangelical excesses) will not be selected. Teachers of Islam will be approved by MUIS. Buddhist and Hindu teachers will be those accepted by the Singapore Buddhist Federation and the Hindu Advisory Board respectively.

    The syllabuses and textbooks which have been or are being prepared for the four religious knowledge courses, namely, Bible Knowledge, Islamic Religious Knowledge, Buddhist Studies and Hindu Studies, are aimed primarily at informing the students about the religion, its founder or its origins and the universal moral teachings and main beliefs of the religion. For example, in Bible Knowledge, the textbook is the synoptic Gospels which are an account of the life of Christ and his teachings.

    The 'O' level examination at the end of the two-year course will be based entirely on the context of the set books. Students are not expected to provide theological interpretations.

    More importantly, although some rituals are mentioned in the four subjects, the students are not permitted to practise the rituals nor to carry out religious practices in the class. The purpose of the course is therefore to inform and to explain the teachings and beliefs of each of the religions and not to produce converts.

    It should be noted also that two of the courses, namely, Bible Knowledge and Islamic Religious Knowledge, have been aught for many years to thousands of students in Singapore. There have been no complaints on record that any of these classes were being used for conversion.

Column: 374



    Nevertheless, the Schools Division of my Ministry will closely monitor the teaching of the subjects to ensure that no teacher makes use of such classes for conversion purposes.

    As a final safeguard, parents who have fears of religious conversion of their children may ask for exemption from attending these classes. They can opt for Confucian Ethics instead.

SINGAPORE POOLS (PRIVATE) LIMITED

    One of the concessions announced in the 1981 Budget Statement was the reduction in personal income tax. In respect of tax payable for the Year of Assessment 1981, a tax rebate of 10% of total tax liability was granted and in respect of tax payable from Year of Assessment 1982, marginal tax rates will be reduced.
